result.execSummary:
On one or more charges, the deferred prosecution or sentencing agreement(s) on this case were fulfilled, and the charge(s) were dismissed.

The defendant was charged with both OWI (2nd) and Operating w/ PAC (2nd). The defendant was found guilty of OWI (2nd) and the other charge, Operating w/ PAC (2nd) was dismissed by the court.

  • Joseph L. Reichenbach was found guilty of OWI (2nd), an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Per Statute 343.301(g) your operating privileges for operation of Class D vehicles will require that vehicles owned and/or driven by you be equipped with an ignition interlock device.  Must install a mandatory Ignition Interlock Device when defendant obtains an occupational license or regular license.  There is a $50 ignition interlock surcharge imposed.  Only applies to his personal vehicles.

and driver's safety plan.    Any out of pocket costs for the alcohol assessment and driver's safety plan shall be subtracted from the fine and costs in this action, pursuant to sec. 346.65(2e) Wis. Stats.

miscConds.notes: To be paid on a monthly basis through probation.  If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Must pay all costs of supervision and court ordered financial obligations during the term of probation.

If agent recommends, defendant must attend and successfully complete an alcohol assessment and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant is to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.

Defendant to be subject to random testing by his agent.

If agent recommends, defendant must attend and successfully complete a drug assessment, and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.

Defendant to be subject to random testing by his agent.

Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.

Court advised defendant of the DNA submission requirement.

To be paid in full during term of probation.  If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Must pay all costs of supervision and court ordered financial obligations during the term of probation.

timeConds.notes: All but the first 5 days stayed, pending successful completion of probation that includes alcohol and other drug treatment.  Start date to be arranged through his agent.

records.addlTxt: Associated with Charge #1

DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Matousek.  Victim notification complied with. Restitution has been paid in full.  Waive reading of the amended information.   Defendant plead no contest to Counts 1 and 3 of the amended information.    Count 3 will have a diversion agreement proposed.  Count 1 will have a probation recommendation.  Count 7 dismissed by operation of law.  Count 2 dismissed, but read in for sentencing purposes.  Court confirmed the prior OWI conviction with the defendant and Attorney Matousek. Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, constitutional rights with the defendant. Felony warnings give to the defendant by the court.  He understood.   Defense stipulated that there is a factual basis for the pleas.   Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily, knowingly and intelligently entered his pleas and waived his constitutional rights.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the pleas.  Found guilty of  OWI 2nd, contrary to 346.63(1)(a).  Finding withheld on Count 3.  Court discussed the proposed diversion agreement with the defendant.  He stated he understood what it is, what is expected, and he stated he can comply.  Diversion agreement approved by the court.  As to Count 1, a joint recommendation for:  probation.  Follow OWI sentencing guidelines. Statement as to negotiated plea filed with the court. 

Court ordered on count 1:  sentence withheld, 18 months probation.  Fine and costs of $1,555.00.  Pay monthly through probation.   Any out of pocket costs for the alcohol assessment and driver's safety plan shall be subtracted from the fine and costs in this action, pursuant to sec. 346.65(2e) Wis. Stats.  18 month revocation of DL & IID installation. Only applies to his personal vehicles.   Alcohol assessment and DSP.  50 days jail.  All but the first 5 days stayed, pending successful completion of probation that includes alcohol and other drug treatment.    Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants.  Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  AODA and recommended treatment. Defendant to be subject to random alcohol testing by his agent.     The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions. Court advised defendant of the DNA submission requirement.   Arrange start date for the jail sentence with his agent.  Bond continues as to count 3.

Bond is modified to allow the defendant to attend his nephew/godson's wedding in Colorado on August 23-31, 2016.  Therefore the defendant is relieved from his obligations to submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request on August 23-31, 2016.  Furthermore, the defendant is allowed to be present at a facility that serves alcohol on the dates of August 25 and 26, 2016, for purposes of his nephew/godson's wedding.  All other bond conditions shall remain in effect.
for modification of bond.

DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Matousek.  Court questioned defendant on his understanding of the waiver of preliminary hearing.  He stated he understood.  Court found that the defendant knowingly and intelligently waived his right to have a preliminary hearing.

Faxed a copy of the stipulation and order for modification of bond to the sheriff's dept.

Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.    As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.    Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle on the highways until properly reinstated in the State of Wisconsin, and without an IID installed after 4:30 pm. 3/29/16.

Ordered Modified 5/4/16.  Bond is modified to allow the defendant to attend his son's wedding in Brainerd, MN on June 3, 4 and 5, 2016.  Therefore, the defendant is relieved from his obligations to submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request on June 3, 4 and 5, 2016.  However, the defendant must test the morning of June 3, 2016 before he leaves, and must test on the evening of June 5, 2016 when he returns home.  Furthermore, the defendant is allowed to be present at a facility that serves alcohol on the dates of June 3 and 4 for purposes of his son's wedding. All other bond conditions shall remain in effect.  He may not possess or consume alcohol however.
